subject: Re: [junit] question about Assert.assertEquals
msgSnippet: ... Eh?  instanceof returns true if the left-hand side argument is a subclass as well.  It also returns false if its null, which makes it particularly handy
messageBody:
--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> Some people will suggest using an instanceof check in your equals
> method. This fails if you subclass Point.

Eh? instanceof returns true if the left-hand side argument is a
subclass as well. It also returns false if its null, which makes it
particularly handy for objects.

If you mean that it ends up breaking symmetry if subclassed, I'll
agree. However, as Joshua Bloch pointed out (to me at least) in
Effective Java, "There isn't any way to extend an instantiable object
and add an aspect while preserving the Equals contract". You're either
going to break symmetry or transitivity no matter how you do it.

-Kevin
